abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Rehabilitation Loan in Latvia. The
            objectives of the Loan were to: (i) assist the Government in
            the design and implementation of the stabilization and
            structural reform program outlined in the Memorandum of
            Economic Reform Policies (MERP); and (ii) help reduce
            further sharp declines in economic activity in key sectors
            during the initial phase of transition. Overall Bank
            performance during implementation is considered to be
            satisfactory. The Borrower's performance was fully
            satisfactory in implementing this Loan. The key lessons
            learned from this project were as follows: (i) policy
            targets for achieving specific stabilization and structural
            reforms need to be realistic to require less need for
            adjustment during Loan implementation; (ii) in designing
            future loans for similar purposes for countries in
            transition, Bank management may wish to consider whether
            more flexible procurement procedures could be employed; (iv)
            the appointment of well qualified procurement and
            disbursement advisors to provide overall project management
            support and training of local counterparts in a project
            implementation unit is very important for the success
            of' an operation; and (v) higher than average resources
            are needed when working with new borrowers, particularly in
            loans that include policy reform components.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rehabilitation Loan Project will
            provide foreign exchange to finance critically-needed
            imports and technical assitance in support of Latvia's
            program of stabilization and economic reform. The Latvian
            Government has embarked on a comprehensive effort to
            restructure the economy on the basis of market principles,
            and the initial stages of the reform program have already
            been implemented. A policy framework of systemic and
            structural reforms has been developed with the assistance of
            the Bank in the following areas: enterprise reform
            (including privatization), procompetition and anti-monopoly
            policies, financial sector reforms and establishment of a
            social safety net.
